Share.d:
Advanced Auto Brightness V3.2

Frustrated with stock adaptive brightness that relies on opaque machine learning predictions? Advanced Auto Brightness (AAB) V3.2 is a ground-up redesign that rejects the "black box" approach in favor of determinism and transparency. It's a complete, 100% plugin-free replacement for Android's native system, giving you unparalleled control through an intuitive command center.

This isn't just a set of rules; it's a "glass box" engineering solution designed for a smooth, natural, and completely personalized experience where you define the logic.

⭐ Why AAB V3.2 is the Definitive Upgrade ⭐

1. The All-in-One Command Center

Forget editing variables. V3.2 features a polished, page-based UI built with native Tasker scenes. It's your one-stop shop for configuration and real-time monitoring.

  • Effortless Navigation: A clean interface, navigated via a central hamburger menu, provides access to all settings pages: General, Reactivity, Misc, Circadian, and Super Dimming.
  • Information & Help: The menu also provides access to a detailed User Guide, license information, and a powerful Live Debug Info screen for advanced monitoring.

2. Live Graphing: See Your Changes, Instantly

The heart of the UI is its live visualization engine. Before you save, you can see a precise graph of how your new settings will behave.

  • Visualize Your Curve: The Brightness Graph plots your custom light-to-brightness curve against a reference, so you can perfectly tune the response for every environment.
  • Tune Out the Jitter: The Reactivity Graph shows you the sensor's "dead-zone" on a logarithmic scale, allowing you to fine-tune the threshold to eliminate annoying flicker.
  • Explore Advanced Features: Dedicated graphs for the Circadian, Super Dimming, and Curve Fitting features let you visualize exactly how AAB will behave.

3. An Engine Built on Smarter Logic

AAB V3.2's backend has been largely rewritten using Java Code for low latency math. It prioritizes user empowerment by offering tools that adapt to you, not the other way around.

  • AAB Learns: Manually adjusting your brightness now trains the system. Use the new Automatic Curve Fitting engine to mathematically recalculate your curve based on your real-world usage.
  • Jitter-Free Stability: A fully configurable, dynamic dead-zone intelligently ignores minor sensor noise that would normally cause flickering.
  • Adaptive Smoothing: Brightness changes are smoothed using a dynamic alpha. Large, intentional changes happen quickly, while small flickers are smoothed away.

⚙️ Your 3-Step Setup Guide ⚙️

  1. THE MOST IMPORTANT STEP: You MUST disable your phone's built-in "Adaptive Brightness" in the Android system settings. If you don't, AAB and the stock system will constantly fight for control.
  2. Grant Permissions: On first launch, AAB will guide you through granting the necessary permissions.
  3. Launch & Configure: Run the Advanced Auto Brightness task from your launcher or Tasker. Flip the master switch on the main Brightness Settings screen to activate the service.

Tuning Your Brightness Curve (Brightness Settings)

This is where you design your core brightness response. The system uses a sophisticated three-part formula to give you precise control where it matters most.

Eliminating Flicker & Handling Overrides (Reactivity Settings)

This screen lets you control sensor behavior. Main thresholds create a smart dead-zone to eliminate jitter from sensor noise.

  • Override Detection: Enabling this allows AAB to detect manual brightness changes. When triggered, AAB pauses and logs the data point for the Curve Fitting engine.

Advanced Features (Circadian & Super Dimming)

AAB includes powerful systems that go beyond a simple lux-to-brightness curve.

  • PWM Sensitive Mode: A hybrid engine that synchronizes hardware brightness with software dimming to simulate DC-Like Dimming.
  • Circadian Scaling: Brightness adapts to time of day relative to sunrise and sunset.
  • Super Dimming: Allows your screen to get darker than Android's minimum using privileged methods or an overlay.

Advanced Auto Brightness

About & License

Version %AAB_Version

This project is a complete, native replacement for Android's stock auto-brightness system, built entirely within Tasker with no plugins required.

It was created by /u/v_uurtjevragen to provide a more intelligent, responsive, and customizable brightness experience.

Acknowledgments

This project wouldn't be possible without the incredible power and flexibility of Tasker, developed by João Dias.

The awesome graphs you see in the settings panels are powered by the Chart.js library.

WebElement.Str:
Advanced Auto Brightness

Welcome to Advanced Auto Brightness

This project is a complete replacement for your phone's built-in auto brightness. Its goal is to provide a smoother, more intelligent, and completely customizable experience that adapts to light the way you want it to.

1. Getting Started: Initial Setup

Setting up involves a few simple steps to grant permissions and activate the service.

  1. Grant Permissions: On first launch, AAB will guide you through granting the necessary permissions for notifications and writing settings. These are essential for the app to function correctly.
  2. Activate the Service: In the main Brightness Settings screen, flip the master switch on the top right. A persistent notification will appear, confirming that AAB is active. This action automatically disables Android's native auto-brightness system.
  3. Set Your Boundaries: Use the hamburger menu (☰) to navigate to Misc. Adjust the Min Brightness and Max Brightness sliders. This defines the absolute darkest and brightest your screen will ever get.
Tip: For phones with OLED screens, setting Min Brightness to a small value like 5 or 10 instead of 0 can prevent "black crush" (loss of detail in dark areas).

2. Navigating the Interface

All settings are accessed via the hamburger menu icon (☰) in the top-left corner. This opens a navigation panel to the various control screens.

  • Brightness Settings: This is the main screen. It defines the shape of your brightness curve. It answers the question: "What brightness level should I have for this amount of ambient light?"
  • Reactivity Settings: This controls the behavior of the sensor. It answers the question: "When should I react to a change in light, and how sensitive should I be?"
  • Misc Settings: This sets the rules and feel of the system. Here you'll find the master brightness limits, animation controls, and global fine-tuning adjustments.
  • Circadian: Configure the circadian brightness feature, which adjusts brightness based on the time of day.
  • Superdimming: Control settings that allow the screen to get darker than the system's default minimum, including the special PWM Sensitive mode.
Your Secret Weapon: Long-press any setting's label to see a detailed tooltip explaining exactly what it does!

3. Tuning Your Brightness Curve (Brightness Settings)

This is where you design your core brightness response. The system uses a sophisticated three-part formula to give you precise control where it matters most.

  • Zone 1 (Darkness to Dim Light):
    • Zone 1 Scaling: This is your main control for low-light environments. Increase it to make the screen get brighter faster in the dark.
    • Zone 1 End: This sets the lux level where "dark" ends and "dim light" begins.
  • Zone 2 (Dim to Medium Light):
    • Zone 2 Scaling & Offset: These two work together to shape the curve for the most common indoor light levels. Adjust them and use the graph to see how they affect the transition.
  • Zone 3 (Bright Light): This zone is handled automatically by a formula that smoothly approaches maximum brightness. This prevents the screen from becoming blindingly bright too quickly when you step outside.

Automatic Curve Fitting

Instead of manually tuning the curve, you can teach AAB your preferences. The optimization engine will automatically calculate the best possible curve based on your real-world usage.

  1. Create Override Points: Simply use your phone normally. When you feel the brightness is not quite right, manually adjust the system brightness slider. If Override Detection is enabled (in Reactivity Settings), AAB will save this as a data point.
  2. Gather Data: Do this in at least 9 different lighting conditions (e.g., a dark room, a dim lamp, a bright office, near a window, outdoors). The more points you have, the better the fit will be.
  3. Suggest a Curve: Go to the Brightness Graph. If you have enough data points, a "Suggest values" button will appear. Tap it to see suggestions for parameters.
  4. Review & Apply: The curve fitting engine will analyze your points and calculate the optimal parameters for all three zones. It will display a toast summary of how well the new curve fits your data and detailed diagnostics in the \%AAB_Test variable. Inspect the results visually by drawing the graph. If you're happy with the results simply hit "Save & Apply".
Tip: The curve fitting engine provides technical diagnostics like R², nRMSE, and bias. A detailed technical analysis is contained in the \%AAB_Test variable.

4. Eliminating Flicker (Reactivity Settings)

A common issue with stock auto-brightness is jitter: annoying fluctuations from minor sensor noise. This screen lets you eliminate it by creating a smart dead zone. The screen will only react when the light change is significant enough.

  • The Thresholds: Dark, Dim, and Bright Threshold control the size of this dead zone (as a percentage) for different light levels. Higher values mean more stability but less responsiveness.
  • The Curve: Curve Mid and Slope control how the dead zone smoothly transitions between the Dim and Bright threshold values you set.

5. Advanced Features

AAB includes powerful systems that go beyond a simple lux-to-brightness curve.

Dynamic Scaling (The Circadian Engine)

This feature, accessible from the Circadian menu, adjusts the overall brightness curve based on the time of day relative to sunrise and sunset. You can configure the screen to be naturally brighter during the day and dimmer at night, with smooth transitions in the morning and evening, mimicking natural light progression.

Super Dimming & PWM Sensitive Mode

For comfortable viewing in pitch-black rooms, Super Dimming allows your screen to get darker than Android's minimum. It intelligently detects if you have elevated access for direct control; otherwise, it uses a screen filter overlay to achieve the effect.

Some OLED screens use a technique called Pulse Width Modulation (PWM) at low brightness levels, which can cause a "flicker" that is perceptible to sensitive users. AAB offers a solution:

  • PWM Sensitive Mode: Found in the Superdimming settings, this special mode avoids PWM flicker. Instead of lowering the hardware brightness into the flicker range, it sets a minimum hardware brightness (your PWM Threshold) and uses a software screen overlay to achieve even lower perceived brightness. This provides a flicker-free, DC-like dimming experience.
IMPORTANT WARNING: The PWM Threshold should be set to the lowest possible value that eliminates visible flicker for you. Setting this value excessively high forces your screen's pixels to remain at a high power level, with dimming achieved only by the software overlay. This can cause accelerated screen aging and increase the risk of permanent burn-in on OLED displays. Use this feature with caution. The author of this project is not liable for any damage to your device resulting from improper configuration of this setting.

Manual Override

If you enable "Use override detection" in the Reactivity Settings, manually adjusting your phone's brightness slider will automatically pause AAB and post a notification. You can resume the service by simply tapping the "Resume" action in the notification.

Emergency Recovery: The Panic Button

Because AAB allows for powerful control over brightness and screen overlays, it is possible to accidentally configure a setting that makes your screen entirely black or unresponsive to touch (e.g., setting an overlay to 100% opacity).

If you find yourself unable to see or interact with the screen:

  • Shake your device vertically (up and down) while the phone is upside down (typically front facing camera at the bottom).

The system will acknowledge the command with a distinct S.O.S. vibration pattern (three short, three long, three short). It will immediately stop all automation loops, disable Super Dimming overlays, and force the screen brightness to maximum.

Test It First: It is highly recommended to test this motion once while your screen is on, so you know exactly how much force is required to trigger the reset before you actually need it.

6. Visualize Before You Apply: Use the Graphs!

Don't guess what your changes are doing. AAB provides real-time graphs to show you the exact impact of your settings before you save them. Tap the graph icon on any settings page.

  • Brightness Graph: The Teal Line is your custom curve (or the suggested curve). Your manual override points will appear as blue dots, allowing you to see how well the curve fits your preferences. The Yellow Line is a reference.
  • Reactivity Graph: This visualizes your stability curve, showing how much the ambient light needs to change before the brightness adjusts.
  • Other Graphs: Explore the graphs in the Circadian and Superdimming sections to understand how those features will behave over time and at different brightness levels.

7. Saving Your Work

Your adjustments are temporary until you save them using the buttons at the bottom of each settings page.

  • Save & Apply: Saves your changes and immediately applies them.
  • Reset: Reverts the settings on the current screen to their original defaults.
  • Exit: Closes the control panel without saving any changes you've made.

Enjoy your new intelligent auto brightness!

Select the date and/or location for the sunrise/sunset time fetching. If unset, the task will use today's sunrise/sunset (highly recommended!)
Enables or disables the entire experimental circadian scaling feature. When disabled, the simpler 'Scale' and 'Offset' multipliers from the Misc tab are used instead.
⚠️ Invalid brightness settings. Negative values in calculated cells. Can't be saved!
⚠️ Graph might be non-sensical due to scale transition factor being greater than 1.
Please be patient. Generating the graph might take a few seconds.
Adjusts the duration of the transition between the daytime and nighttime scale factors. A higher value creates a longer, more gradual blend around sunrise and sunset.
Use notifications to keep the service alive and show 'paused' notifications.

Current throttle is a time based gatekeeper for the main brightness loop.
α is used in exponential moving average calculation: smoothed sensor read=(new raw read×α)+(old smoothed read×(1-α))
Please be patient. Generating the graph might take a few seconds.
Sets the brightness level (%AAB_MinBright-%AAB_MaxBright) where the high-end compression is centered. This is the 'knee' of the curve. Lower values will start tapering the scale factor earlier.
Use a quick settings tile set to position 3 (Preferences > Action > Quick settings task > _QSToggleAABService V2).
This only works for Tasker. It does nothing for the exported .apk
⚠️ Taper midpoint cannot exceed current maximum brightness (%AAB_MaxBright)
Controls the slope of the dynamic range compression.

Notifications disabled!
⚠️ Service might be stopped via aggressive battery management.
Displays the current (un)compressed scale factor based on the time of day, (the current screen brightness) and your 'Spread' setting.
Hardware mode Loops: %loops, wait step: %wait ms Java loop duration: %java_step_duration ms Target brightness: %AAB_CurrentBright Maximum target: %max_target Minimum target: %min_target

Action.label: Shows 1 decimal point in the scene below %AAB_DimmingThreshold lux and is used for higher accuracy in super dimming.

Action.Str: Software dimming Loops: %loops, wait step: %wait ms Java loop duration: %java_step_duration ms Target brightness: %AAB_CurrentBright

Action.label: Bias is necessary because a screen at 0 brightness should not equal a black screen
This and the next block should mathematically never trigger. But I really don't want black screens.
This is 99% on a 0-255 scale
This constant determines how dark the screen gets at 0 brightness. Default = 95% opaque as a maximum value.

Action.Str: Gamma-like exponent. Controls the shape of the dimming curve. Higher values keep the screen brighter for longer and fade more steeply near the threshold; lower values dim more quickly. Adjusts how brightness transitions, not how much(!)

Action.label: Calling this task repeatedly from the DC-like dimming tasks enables a smoother update of the Color Filter scene's rectangle element than waiting for %AAB_HexOverlay to update.

Action.Str: ⚠️ Safety Warning: Brightness too low at 1000 Lux (%safe_val / 255). Please adjust parameters.

Action.label: This pattern is S.O.S. in morse code.
This is redundant, but better safe than sorry.

Action.Str: Brightness is only changed when the change in lux exceeds this threshold, i.e. the lux measurements need to be outside of the dead zone. This prevents jitter.

The log-transformed lux level where the system is most sensitive to change. Think of it as the 'center point' of the reactivity curve.
E.g. 10^%AAB_ThreshMidpoint equals %aab_10xthreshmidpoint lx
Minimum wait cannot exceed maximum wait!
Maximum wait cannot be lower than minimum wait!
The reactivity level in complete darkness. A higher value means the brightness is more stable and less 'jumpy' in very dark rooms.
The baseline reactivity for most situations. A lower value makes the system more responsive to small decreases in light.
The baseline reactivity for bright, outdoor light. A higher value prevents tiny shadows (like your hand) from causing annoying brightness dips.
Controls how quickly the reactivity changes as you move from dim to bright light. Higher value = more abrupt transition.
Sets the lowest brightness level the screen will ever use. Recommended to be > 0 on OLED screens to avoid 'black crush'.
⚠️ Graph invalid. Negative values in calculated cells. Won't be drawn!
Controls how quickly brightness rises in dim light. Recommended: 1 to 5
The number of steps in a brightness change animation. More steps create a smoother, but slightly slower, transition.
The shortest time (in milliseconds) between animation steps. Controls how fast large brightness changes feel.
The longest time (in milliseconds) between animation steps. Controls how slowly small, subtle brightness changes occur.
Enable this ONLY if auto-brightness seems unresponsive on your device. This may cause brightness to become unstable or flicker.
A global multiplier for the entire brightness curve. Use it to adjust the overall contrast. >1 stretches the curve brighter, <1 compresses it dimmer.
A simple brightness boost or cut. This value is added to (or subtracted from) the final brightness across all light levels.
Hinge point to enable smooth transition from zone 1 (dark) to zone 2 (dim to medium).
Higher values give a major boost in medium light. Recommended: 3 to 10
Controls how much to smooth out sensor readings. Higher values react faster to small light changes, but may increase jitter. Lower values are more stable, but might feel sluggish.
Subtle but powerful "offset" for the midrange curve. Lower values make the transition from dark to dim light more gradual and smooth. Recommended: -300 to %aab_zone1end.
⚠️ Invalid brightness settings. Negative values in calculated cells. Can't be saved!
Sets the lux level where 'dim light' ends and 'indoor light' begins. Typically for moving from a dark room to a lit one.
Hinge point to enable smooth transition from zone 2 (dim to medium) to zone 3 (bright).
Sets the lux level where 'indoor light' ends and 'bright outdoor light' begins. Affects the transition when going outside.
Current light sensor reading after smoothing and other formulas are applied and the corresponding brightness level.
⚠️ Invalid brightness settings. Negative values in calculated cells. Can't be saved!
⚠️ Invalid brightness settings. Negative values in calculated cells. Can't be saved!
⚠️ Invalid brightness settings. Can't be saved!
Caution: Low brightness may be unreadable on some devices. Test in a dark room.
⚠️ Invalid wait time settings. Can't be saved!
⚠️ Invalid brightness settings. Negative values in calculated cells. Can't be saved!
A global multiplier for the entire brightness curve. Automatically calculated via the circadian scaling settings.
This is the screen brightness below which super dimming kicks in.
This is the lowest hardware screen brightness. Software dimming is applied below this point.
Controls the maximum super dimming strength. Value shows what happens without circadian effects.
Point where the logic switches from zone 1 curve (linear) to the curve for the remainder of the range (sigmoidal)
Controls how wide the scale shifts over the day. E.g. %AAB_DimSpread results in a super dimming strength ranging from %min to %max. Only active when circadian scaling is enabled!
Controls how gradual the super dimming kicks in and how it behaves as brightness approaches %AAB_MinBright lx. <1: hard transition, not recommended. 1: linear transition. >1 soft(er) transition.
⚠️ Invalid brightness settings. Negative values in calculated cells. Can't be saved!
⚠️ Unprivileged super dimming will use a semi transparent overlay. Battery drain might be excessive!
Enables or disables the entire experimental circadian scaling feature. When disabled the strength setpoint is used as a maximum value throughout the day.
⚠️ Unprivileged super dimming will use a semi transparent overlay. Battery drain might be excessive!

Displays the current (un)compressed scale factor based on the time of day, (the current screen brightness) and your 'Spread' setting.

Enables or disables the software dimming feature. When enabled the max hardware brightness is fixated to the PWM threshold.
Sets the highest brightness level the screen will ever use. Can be used to cap the max brightness to save battery.

Action.label: High priority notification when the service starts.

Action.Str: Foreground notification. Please don't dismiss this notification. It's important for maintaining functionality.

Action.label:
Inertia regularization factor, prevents overfitting. Lower values adapt quicker to new measurements, while higher values will prioritize the existing curve until a lot of override data is provided.

After you have set your personal curve that captures your preferences, setting Tau to a high value is recommended in order to prevent overfitting to new measurements

Recommended range: 0 - 5

Action.Str: ⚠️ Dimming strength will be clamped to minimum 0 or maximum 65.
⚠️ Exponent cannot be set to 0 or lower!
⚠️ Dimming threshold cannot be set outside brightness bounds (%AAB_MinBright - %AAB_MaxBright)
⚠️ Not set! PWM exponent should be set around 2.2 (range: 0.2 and 3.5).
Delta factor cannot be 0 or lower! Field not stored.
Zone 2 Offset cannot exceed Zone 1 End!
Zone 2 Offset cannot exceed Zone 1 End!
Zone 2 End cannot be smaller than Zone 1 End!

Action.label: In the exported kid app, the logo is properly packaged by the app factory.

Action.Str: Please tap learn in order to learn how to grant Write Secure Settings permissions to this app.
⚠️ Unprivileged will draw a semi-transparent overlay and eat your battery. Not recommended! Please check notification for an alternative.
Preview of overlay color for current brightness and/or time of day.
System will not detect manual brightness changes.
Will now detect manual brightness changes.
Please follow the instructions in the next pop up to grant Write Secure Settings permissions to %AAB_Package. This will enable a more efficient method for the Super Dimming functionality.
Displays the current privilege. Shizuku privilege will use shell commands (reasonably efficient, albeit slow) to enable super dimming.
Displays your current privilege. ⚠️ Unprivileged will draw a semi-transparent overlay and eat your battery. Not recommended to enable super dimming!
⚠️ Privilege not set. Please tap the Check Privilege button.
Displays the current privilege. ADB WiFi shell commands are reasonably efficient albeit slow. Note: May need re-enabling after rebooting your device.
Displays your current privilege. %AAB_Privilege privilege will efficiently use Custom Settings actions to enable super dimming.
Please tap learn in order to learn how to grant Write Secure Settings permissions to this app.

The dynamic scale engine requires location access in order to properly acquire times for solar events in your location.

Action.label: Prevents this from being unset and signals no write secure settings.
The Goto action is meant to be efficient, i.e. before doing any work or nagging the user.
This fallback purely exists for the exported kid app version of the project.

Vals.net.dinglisch.android.tasker.RELEVANT_VA: <StringArray sr=""><_array_net.dinglisch.android.tasker.RELEVANT_VARIABLES0>%http_cookies Cookies The cookies the server sent in the response in the Cookie:COOKIE_VALUE format. You can use this directly in the 'Headers' field of the HTTP Request action</_array_net.dinglisch.android.tasker.RELEVANT_VARIABLES0><_array_net.dinglisch.android.tasker.RELEVANT_VARIABLES1>%http_data Data Data that the server responded from the HTTP request.</_array_net.dinglisch.android.tasker.RELEVANT_VARIABLES1><_array_net.dinglisch.android.tasker.RELEVANT_VARIABLES2>%http_file_output File Output Will always contain the file's full path even if you specified a directory as the File to save.</_array_net.dinglisch.android.tasker.RELEVANT_VARIABLES2><_array_net.dinglisch.android.tasker.RELEVANT_VARIABLES3>%http_response_code Response Code The HTTP Code the server responded</_array_net.dinglisch.android.tasker.RELEVANT_VARIABLES3><_array_net.dinglisch.android.tasker.RELEVANT_VARIABLES4>%http_headers() Response Headers The HTTP Headers the server sent in the response. Each header is in the 'key:value' format</_array_net.dinglisch.android.tasker.RELEVANT_VARIABLES4><_array_net.dinglisch.android.tasker.RELEVANT_VARIABLES5>%http_response_length Response Length The size of the response in bytes</_array_net.dinglisch.android.tasker.RELEVANT_VARIABLES5></StringArray>

Action.label: Calc_sun

Action.Str: Failed to retrieve Sun data today. Will use yesterday's data. Toggle 'use circadian scaling' to retry.
Failed to retrieve Sun data today. Will use yesterday's data. Toggle 'use circadian scaling' to retry.

Action.label: start_loop

Action.Str: Controls how wide the scale shifts over the day. E.g. 20 results in a multiplier ranging from 0.8 to 1.2

Action.label: Shows 1 decimal point in the scene below %AAB_DimmingThreshold lux and is used for higher accuracy in super dimming.

Action.Str: Controls the sharpness of the transition curve between the day and night scale factors. Higher values create a more rapid change around solar noon and midnight.
